pros: Centennial truly feels like a family, co-workers truly care about each other and managers are very compassionate. There is a lot of flexibility within the roles and great benefits including health, dental, disability and life insurance, pension plan, education incentives, outstanding maternity leave benefits, plus many more.
cons: Things can move slowly at Centennial, there is a lot of red tape and bureaucracy. Unfortunately the only way to get promoted is if someone leaves, which makes it disheartening since there are people there for 30+ years...

review_title: 2.5 Star Rating  - Salaries are ok but treatment of Contract teaching staff is
pros: Great students ,  variety of cultural backgrounds, overall offer some good tools and courses available for teachers to  understand teaching strategies and challenges .
cons: As contract faculty you have no job security. You are at the mercy  of the Chair and Dean of your School. There is little consistency  from School to School on how staff is treated.  School of Hospitality and Tourism in particularly shows little respect for staff.

job_title: Instructor; School of Hospitality, Tourism & Culinary Arts in Toronto, ON
pros: Great college to work for overall. Many resources for students and staff. Most of the people I worked with were caring and thoughtful. A real focus on student success in many departments.
cons: The department for which I was teaching was going through major changes in management. They seemed to possess very poor leadership skills and a lack of vision.

job_title: Professor, Adult Continuing Education Business Program in Toronto, ON
pros: The institution is open to students of all ages, backgrounds, abilities and skill levels.  It is a good place for new immigrants to learn about the Canadian culture and social mechanisms.  It is also a safe place for those who are not clear on their future goals and capabilities to find their way.  The professors in the various continuing education programs have 'real life' experience.
cons: Not sure if the certification programs have the necessary support and required discipline from the leadership in the faculty.

pros: Lots of nice people and learning experiences. Diverse student body. Leadership very positive and supportive of students. Well managed as a business too bad education is a business but still well done.
cons: Big disconnect between the social justice "brand"and how those things play out on the ground. Typical contemporary neoliberal education system - people working real hard to take that edge off but lots of contradictions. Some schools managed way better than others. Too many long time employees staying in one place - very clique-like and exclusionary - the in and out membership very obvious. Move people around - let the blood mix.

pros:
Friendly people, good co-worker environment
Collaborative environment
cons:
Not much room for advancement
management typically hired from outside, who in turn hire those from within their network and circle
A good deal of nepotism and favoritism
No management opportunities for front line employees who have spent years in the organization
No mentorship or development of employees
No performance management
Employee engagement at an all time low
No real diversity at upper management and sr management levels

pros: Great co-workers, helpful and supportive.  Management was also hands-on and available for questions and concerns.
cons: The IT Department rules its little fiefdom with an iron fist and with little or no concern for follow-up or even implementing basic tasks. After repeated reminders from both staff and management, it took over two weeks to get a new staff log-in registered for access to the grading and curriculum database.

pros: Management supports everyday learning (on-the-job, too) for skill sets you didn't have coming in, but could be of use to the College.
cons: There's a definite disconnect between other departments and teams (sometimes within the same departments).

review_title: Difficult politics but lots of perks
pros: If you manage to get to the full-time faculty stream it's got a ton of perks (lots of vacation, benefits, etc)
cons: The administrative structure is dysfunctional and bloated, with a cult of personality around the college president. Especially following the 2017 strike, there is a highly contentious dynamic between faculty and administration that makes for an (at best) difficult work environment.
